articles.title: Actin 'avalanches' may make memories stick - Phys.org
articles.description: If you're on skis, you want to avoid avalanches. But when the right kind happen in your brain, you shouldn't worry. You won't feel them. They're probably to your benefit.

articles.description: "It looks as though the stars are being kicked out from the center."

Yeet!
New research suggests that the supernovae in the center of our galaxy could be constantly launching stars out toward its outermost reaches.

articles.title: Scientists Are Brightening Clouds Over The Great Barrier Reef To Protect Dying Coral - Forbes
articles.description: This year, Australia’s Great Barrier Reef is suffering its third mass bleaching event in just five years as climate change and record warm oceans threaten to wipe out one of the wonders of the natural world.

articles.title: Quantum entanglement offers unprecedented precision for GPS, imaging and beyond - Science Daily
articles.description: Engineers have demonstrated for the first time that it's possible to connect a network of sensors through quantum entanglement. The experiment opens a door to unprecedented levels of sensitivity in GPS navigation, medical imaging and astronomy.
articles.content: Your phone's GPS, the WiFi in your house and communications on aircraft are all powered by radio-frequency waves, or RF waves, which carry information from a transmitter at one point to a sensor at another. The sensors interpret this information in different … [+6356 chars]

articles.title: Eurasian ice sheet collapse raised seas eight metres: study - Bangkok Post
articles.description: PARIS - The melting of the Eurasian ice sheet around 14,000 years ago lifted global sea levels by about eight metres, according to new research published Monday that highlights the risks of today's rapid ice cap melt.
